SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Concerning the jobs for the dole issue, I think everybody is missing the point in this debate. While the former government, the current government and governments all around the world are thrashing around for an answer to the unemployment situation, we just have to realise that downsizing, rationalisation, privatisation, technology replacing jobs and the fact that there are no manual jobs out there any more means that we have to find a new definition for work. We have to find what meaningful occupations we can put a lot of these people into in the years ahead because we just cannot provide employment in the traditional sense.

SPEECH.PARA: We keep bashing our heads against the wall accusing each other of lacking any sort of vision in this area. We have to sit down and work out how we are going to soak up these people and whether we can work out jobs programs that are meaningful. They will be part‐time. They might be two days a week ad infinitum. They might be grafted onto other public programs, but we cannot look at the traditional way of providing jobs as we have done in the past.

I will reserve judgment on the government's radical changes to the provision of employment services through the PEPEs and so on. I am sceptical of how the new competitive arrangements will work in regional areas like mine where there are only limited employers looking for young people and where I do not envisage there will be the same level of competition as in the non‐rural electorates.

As well, this market‐driven system will mean that the brokers will target only the cream of the unemployed for their programs, for only they will deliver the bounty on offer at the end of the day. Of course, with the new youth allowance, families with 16‐ and 17‐year‐old kids cannot afford to keep them. They too will miss out on these training opportunities. Believe me, they will be out on the streets in regional towns and we will have an increase in delinquency.

There could also—and I would hate to support the comment necessarily that Senator Kernot made—be more youth suicides because of this hopelessness that is out there. I know members of the coalition are concerned about this aspect of the youth allowance. I would ask the government to have a good, hard look at it again because it is going to leave many youths outside the safety net. We cannot just graft our youth back onto the family. It is simplistic nonsense to talk about this wonderful family concept as the answer. It is not the answer. We have dysfunctional families out there and we have got to take cognisance of that fact.

Concerning Austudy, to gauge the nature of public sentiment regarding the operation of Austudy I will quote some constituent letters which the parliamentary secretary should be interested in. This one says:
Austudy is a nightmare. You need an accountant to fill it in, but if you can't afford one of these you are penalised because you put the wrong answers in the wrong boxes.
Another says:
Just from my own experience, the emotional and financial strain that has been placed on our family makes you realise the enormous amount people have suffered.
Another says:

BREAK.PARA: I fail to see how a family who qualifies for a low income rebate on tax does not qualify for Austudy. Do any of you live hand to mouth by day? Try it. You are institutionalising a system which will leave people no other option than to try to cheat it.

That says it all, and to think that this same test will now be applied across the board in the youth allowance. This test is going to occur despite rulings by at least one member of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal stating that the test is doomed to failure unless its whole structure is changed.

The test is far too complicated for the average person to comprehend. The reliance on estimates of future expenditure is ridiculous. It does not allow for the fluctuating nature of income derived from many rural farms and small businesses. The benchmark in many cases does not line up fairly with PAYE equivalent incomes. The phone service is inadequate, and while I am sure it has caught some of the smarties that it was meant to, the evidence I have seen—and we have done heaps of surveys in my electorate conducted by my youth officer who has put so much time and effort into this—is that in some cases it has also discriminated against the very people it was designed to protect.

Finally, the government, in its desperation to cut funding outlays, has severely hurt Charles Sturt University in my electorate, and others, with cuts to the Commonwealth industry placement scheme. We all know what the Wood royal commission found about police training and so on. Charles Sturt has 3,000 students. It has lost $10 million in support. It must be restored, not patched up as the government is trying to do with it, it must be restored because this is the sort of study that Charles Sturt is now involved in that is vital to the community. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In continuing my contribution in this debate, I want to say something about the work for the dole program. I would like to put it in the context that certainly we cannot say that it will not do any good—it may well do some good in some areas—but we believe it is a second‐rate program. I believe it is a lazy program where very little thought was put into constructing it in the first place. One of the really great concerns I have about the work for the dole program is that it does not contain any provision for training, nor does it contain any provision for recognition of the skills that may be obtained during the short period of time that these people will be in employment.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of people have looked at this particular problem, in particular, Richard Sweet from the Dusseldorf Foundation, who recognises that the people who work for the dole will be people on the fringe of the labour market who, for some period of time, may not actually get into full‐time employment. These people may well work for a month or a shorter period of time, they may move on to another job or may be unemployed for a while. But as they move through this range of part‐time work, they are not acquiring any recognition of the skills that they will probably attain during this period of employment.

This is a great weakness in this program. I appeal to the government to look very closely at recognising the skills that people acquire during this period of training. They should be certified so that, as they move through their working life, they can take these qualifications with them. They should have a certificate which says that they have worked for X period of time in this particular type of work and that they acquired certain skills while doing it. If that weakness in the program is rectified, the unemployed people who go into this program will benefit greatly.

I have concerns about other areas of the work for the dole program. It appears to me that the government is taking a fairly pessimistic view of employment growth. I do not think it would have introduced this type of program if it felt that unemployment levels were going to drop. I believe that the government does not have any programs or plans to overcome unemployment.

It appears that this scheme was introduced very hastily. It was introduced by the minister through a very short statement. There were many other problems confronting the government at the time. People could be excused for saying that this was a smokescreen to take attention away from some of the government's other problems.

Coming from a trade union background, I am concerned about the people who work for the dole. This program will be award free. Their rights will not be protected while they are working. They will not come under the recognised workers compensation provisions, although I understand that there may be some insurance that will protect them if they are injured. Members on this side of the House are concerned that people who work for the dole will not be covered by an appropriate industrial award.

Once again, this contrasts very distinctly with the programs of the previous Labor government. People who worked in labour market programs were covered by an appropriate industrial award. I believe this is an attack on the awards system that has protected working‐class people in this country for many years. Quite clearly, this government is trying to weaken the trade union movement and it is trying to weaken award coverage. Whether it is intended or not in the work for the dole proposal, this is certainly what is happening.

Interestingly, many employer organisations are saying that this program will not make people job ready. For a start, it is for a short period of time—only two days a week—and so people will not be conditioned to arrive at work on time, do a good day's work, go home and then come back the next day, and do that on a continuing basis. If people who have been out of work for a period of time are going to get job ready, they need to have continuation of employment. They do not need spasmodic periods, where they work for two days one week and two days the next. I believe that the government is considering the possibility of bringing that all together so that people will work for a full week or for a fortnight, and then maybe have a period of time off. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I return to the issue of youth unemployment. I remind the chamber that Mr Howard said that youth unemployment was the biggest social problem facing Australia. He went into the election campaign committing himself to doing big things for the young unemployed of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I touch on the question of work for the dole, which will apply, for example, to 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds. I have a question for the government: if I am a 19‐year‐old and, on the basis of the announcement going to the issue of youth allowance, based on my parents' household income I am not entitled to unemployment benefits, is there a guarantee that, if I am required to work on a compulsory basis, as suggested by the government, will I receive a payment for that compulsory requirement to participate in the work for the dole program?

I also raise what I find a strange proposition. I refer in passing to the Green Corps. The Green Corps is very small when compared with the old LEAP program. The majority of participants in Green Corps to date have actually had jobs or been in full‐time education. I find it strange that at the end of their program they are entitled to an additional allowance of $500 to go on to a further training opportunity.

Why isn't a similar allowance available, for example, to people who will be compulsorily required to work for the dole? Work for the dole is not going to go to some people who have been fortunate enough in the past to have had jobs or been engaged in full‐time training or education opportunities. Surely those participants should be encouraged at the end of a compulsory requirement to undertake work for the dole to a grant of, say, $500—similar to Green Corps—to go on to a training opportunity.

I say that because, whilst I have serious problems with the question of work for the dole, the value of some of the labour market programs such as LEAP was that that actually gave the young person the opportunity to work themselves out from a personal point of view and to come to terms with their lack of discipline in work and some of the personal difficulties that they had. The time was used by them to actually work out what they wanted to do in the future, such as a traineeship or an apprenticeship. In that context, it is very valuable that they be given some additional assistance or encouragement to go on and take up an alternative training opportunity. We are putting aside the question of the value or otherwise of work for the dole and raising what we should be doing for those people who are going to have the stigma of saying to an employer, `Yes, I am a graduate of work for the dole; two days on, five days off. But would you please put that aside because I really want to do something with my life.' The explanation I am looking for from the government is of when we will get some additional encouragement for those people to actually get some financial assistance to go on to alternative training opportunities.

I say that because I think youth unemployment is a major problem. I am vitally concerned with the fact that, after 15 months of this government, not only have they not made a dent in youth unemployment, but youth unemployment has risen in Australia. More importantly, we are getting suburbs and regions of very high youth unemployment. In fact, the national capital, that the Prime Minister has turned his back on as not being good enough as the centre of government any more, is an area of high youth unemployment. Those people out there in the suburbs of Canberra are looking for more than work for the dole and a Green Corps program that largely benefits people in terms of full‐time jobs or training opportunities.

I say in conclusion that we have got major concerns with the performance of this department but not in isolation. It goes to the whole budget strategy of this government. Unless we get a higher level of economic growth we are not going to make a huge impact on reducing unemployment in Australia. The truth of the matter is that the reduction in interest rates to date, and there have been four reductions, are not a vote of confidence with respect to the performance of this government. I suppose the Reserve Bank is doing what this government has failed to do. They are trying to stimulate some investment and encouragement out there. They have finally realised that they should not just be concerned about building on our achievements from the point of view of breaking the back of inflation. They have come to terms with the fact that the Treasurer is wrong to focus just on the question of the rate of inflation and they must be vitally concerned with the issue of unemployment. We have an all‐time high. We have also a deterioration I might say in terms of long‐term unemployment. We need a regional strategy to help those people. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott, Tony, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank all members who participated in the debate this morning because I think that it has been more constructive than these debates sometimes are. Perhaps this is the nature of the committee stage of debate. I do have a few comments to make. Naturally, all members on this side of the House share the concern of all members on that side of the House about the unemployment problem. It is, as the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has frequently said both before and after the election, the most serious problem that Australia faces. I am prepared to attribute good faith to members opposite and I hope members opposite are prepared to attribute good faith to members of the government on this subject.

SPEECH.PARA: Naturally, as a member of the government I am concerned that after 15 months the unemployment problem is not appreciably better than it was at the time of the election. I am concerned, as members opposite are concerned—we are all concerned. The Prime Minister is concerned. One of the reasons the Prime Minister is in England is to talk to the British Prime Minister and then later when he goes to America to the American President about their options for tackling this very problem.

One thing does slightly disappoint me about members opposite. They are quite properly drawing attention to the fact that after 15 months of this government the situation is not markedly different, at least in terms of the statistics, but after 13 years of their government, where were we at? In the 13 years of the recent Labor government, unemployment never dropped below six per cent and averaged over eight per cent. Their government presided over a great deal of restructuring in the private sector and public sector, all of which resulted in job losses. Full‐time jobs only rose by 7,000 between 1991 and 1996, at the same time as the former government ran up government debt of $75 billion.

What I would like from members opposite is a little bit more fair‐mindedness and appreciation that the level of unemployment is a difficulty, tragedy and disaster that many governments in many countries are grappling with. There are no magic wands, there are no quick fixes. If there were magic wands and quick fixes, does anyone think that they wouldn't have been applied long before now?

Briefly, the government's strategy to reduce unemployment has four basic elements.First of all, we want to make the overall economy more buoyant and the very considerable interest rate reductions that we have seen are at the heart of that strategy. Surely we should get some credit at least for putting in place fiscal conditions that made it easier for the Reserve Bank to allow those reductions.

Labour market flexibility is very important. I want to stress that this government is not about reducing wages, this government is about increasing wages. What we want to see is the ability of workers to work more productively and the ability of workers and managers to work productively together so that businesses are more productive. Better training and better education are a very important part of the government's strategy. I will touch on that in a few moments when I respond to some of the comments of the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) about apprenticeships.

Finally, there are some important structural changes that we are putting in place. Work for the dole is an important structural change because we are trying to establish the principle that people ought to be prepared to give something back in return for the support that society gives them.

I appreciate the comments of members opposite that the work for the dole scheme does not involve anything like the formal training that many of the former government's labour market programs involved. But the fact is that members opposite did not oppose the work for the dole scheme when it went through the House. I really think that great indignation from them is slightly phoney, given that they did not oppose it when it went through the House.

The youth allowance changes are also a very important part of changing the culture of this nation. What we are saying with our changes to the benefit situation for people aged 16 to 18 is that they really should be in education or training. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take up a couple of questions raised by the ministerial secretary. In passing, I might refer to the Reuter's poll of this week. It touches on the question of interest rates and suggests there is about a 60 per cent view that there will be a further half per cent reduction in interest rates. It really relates to whether or not it represents confidence in the government's strategy to date, because this is what this poll says.

SPEECH.PARA: Thursday's May labour force data shocked the economic forecasting community. That really is made in the context of the unemployment problem that this government has created.

I was also looking for an explanation from the government about whether or not the department was really comprehensively consulted by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs on the recent announcement going to the immigration intake. What surprises and concerns me is that at a time when the government is trying to argue to the Australian community that it has reduced the migration intake because of the high level of unemployment, in its first 15 months it has in fact increased independent skilled migration by 50 per cent. As we all appreciate, that independent skilled migration group is the untargeted and not matched group with skills and labour market shortages. I raise that because at the same time the government has slashed $269 million from vocational and industry training programs and more than $2 billion out of jobs programs.

I really think it is important that there are ongoing and regular discussions between this department and the department of immigration on matching the skilled requirements of this great nation and the migration intake. What concerns me is that at the time that we have increased the independent skilled migration, the untargeted and not matched program, by 50 per cent, we have got a cut in government employment in these first two budgets of 28,000 jobs, many of which are in regional Australia. There are 8,000 Defence jobs to go. I suggest that jobs will also go as a result of the program of competitive tendering of information technology. There are 700 meat inspectors jobs to go as a result of the AQIS decisions of this budget. Then we have potential job losses of 12,000 as a result of changes to pharmaceuticals.

BREAK.PARA: This is an important process currently under way in this chamber. It is important that we raise questions and queries with a view to trying to get a better understanding of the issues and also to make suggestions about how current programs can be improved. That is why I raised the question of whether, in considering work for the dole—and we moved a series of amendments to improve it, which is not acknowledged by the government today, because we seriously questioned the value of that proposal—another proposal could be considered for a training grant of $500 at the end of work for the dole, similar to that received by people who participate and graduate from the Green Corps.

When you are out there arguing that and, considering the issue of unemployment, that you also base your immigration intake on that now, what comprehensive discussions did or did not occur and what were the issues that were put forward by this department with respect to influencing the government's decision on immigration and the argument that it has been reduced because of the high level of unemployment and the deterioration in employment in Australia as a result of the first 15 months of this government's performance? That is vitally important, because from a bottom line point of view the real problem is that the budget hardly talks about the issue of jobs. It is mentioned once in the speech by the Treasurer (Mr Costello). There is no real job target, as ACCI suggested this week, of six per cent. All the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) can talk about is a cup of Nescafe and being patient.

The 43‐bean solution is inadequate. People are concerned about the loss of 40,300 jobs in one month. We want explanations, not pie in the sky statements that the government is concerned about unemployment, at the same time that it says that people ought to be patient and that 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds should no longer be entitled to unemployment relief if their parents have a household income of $41,500. I would like to see the apprentice minister ring up kids, including kids who are 18 to 20 years of age, and deny them unemployment relief, because I tell you what, he would have a few troubles at home. It is hard enough to negotiate with your kids about pocket money at the moment, let alone saying to 18‐to 20‐year‐olds that they are not entitled to unemployment relief because mum and dad have to bring up a couple more kids. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott, Tony, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —People were very patient for 13 years with the former government. Believe me, if we have that length of time and if we have the same results, we will certainly deserve to be expelled from government.

SPEECH.PARA: To get back to the youth allowance proposal, we are saying that 16‐ to 18‐year‐olds, unless there are some extraordinary circumstances, should be in full‐time education or training. The problem with the former government's policy was that it had young Australians sitting in the pinball parlours and the video parlours of our inner cities. I do not pretend for a moment that that is what members opposite intended, but that was what their policy allowed and that is what our policy is going to prevent.

I am attempting to answer the points made by the honourable member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson)—
Opposition members interjecting—

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. One of the other issues that the honourable member for Batman raised was the Green Corps. In concluding these comments prompted by the contribution of the honourable member of Batman, let me just say again that I think there is a real problem today when we have members opposite running around increasing the gloom and despair felt by some people in Australia. These are difficult times for many Australians. No‐one pretends otherwise. We have not entered an economic nirvana, just as we were not in an economic nirvana for the 13 years of the former government. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Banks, who has been attempting to interject, should remain silent. He should participate in the spirit of this chamber which is not shouting across the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that I should take up the obvious self‐deception of the parliamentary secretary in relation to two matters that he has spoken about. The first point is about school participation. The suggestion that has been put forward by this government is that it has some form of policy mortgage on the idea that young Australians should seek to better their educational opportunities rather than to be placed on unemployment benefits. The reality is that the period when Australia saw the greatest growth in participation at secondary and tertiary education was during the last 13 years of a Labor government.

SPEECH.PARA: Before that period, participation rates nationally were below any international comparisons. We had literally thousands of our best and brightest people unable to go past year 10 in their education—

TALK.START.PARA: —The rates were below 30 per cent.

—They were below 30 per cent. Thousands were without a framework to enable them to go on into higher education, into post‐secondary education through the technical and further education system and the universities. What the former government did was to radically transform the pattern of youth education in this country. A great majority of young people now complete year 12 education, and the participation levels through tertiary and post‐secondary education have massively increased. But there will still be those who complete their education at year 10. There is no way that this nation is going to have a system whereby all Australians will benefit from participating in education past year 10. That is the reality.

SPEECH.PARA: A failure to provide any employment opportunities for those people is the charge we sheet home to this government. In the past, when it was in opposition, the government criticised us for putting in place labour market programs which had a significant training component, saying that that was shifting people from the unemployment market and into `mickey mouse' schemes, as it described them, in order to take them out of the unemployment statistics. But those so‐called mickey mouse schemes all had elements of training to increase people's employability and job readiness.

What this government is now doing is putting in place an economic regime that simply says, `We will park you in the education system which is already bursting at the seams, notwithstanding that there is no discernible benefit that you will achieve and that there is certainly a disbenefit to the overall participation rates of those who would go on into tertiary and secondary education, because they could have got some benefit from it. We will park in the system all you people for whom that system will contribute no benefit at all, and that is the only way that you are going to receive any support from this government.'

To the extent that they shift people who are genuinely seeking employment across from the job search task into fruitless educational endeavour, they will take people off the unemployment lists. This is a way of disguising long‐term and short‐term unemployment amongst Australia's youth. For an opposition that had said that national unemployment amongst youth was a disgrace, what they are doing now in government is avoiding any responsibility whatsoever. What are they going to say? My colleague the member for Franklin (Mr Quick) made the point that, in Tasmania, there are going to be some 700 people who will now go into the already bulging high schools, in circumstances where there is nothing to give them any net advantage—simply because that will be their only way of gaining any income support. The other point I would make about the independent category in migration is that Parliamentary Secretary Abbott simply misunderstands. There is no requirement for an independent applicant to demonstrate any employment need in this country whatsoever. The rest of the labour market programs require that; and what we have said is that the independent category should be scrapped and that all skilled migration should be linked to labour market needs in this country. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott, Tony, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do intend to try to give explanations to as much as is capable of explanation in the various accusations and interjections from those members opposite. One important issue that the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) raised earlier was this whole question of apprenticeships and traineeships. The member for Batman seems to be suggesting that we should resurrect Working Nation, with all its $2 billion a year expense. Is the shadow Treasurer (Mr Gareth Evans) going to provide the member for Batman with $2 billion? Can the member for Batman guarantee that should he be whisked magically onto the government benches, that he would have an extra $2 billion to spend on this? Is that the kind of guarantee that the member for Batman can give, because if he cannot give that guarantee, he is exposed as a phoney, as someone who waxes self‐righteous in opposition but does nothing in government.

BREAK.PARA: What are the answers that the member for Batman has? So far, the only answer that the member for Batman has come up with is the idea of job sharing. Job sharing was described as a ludicrous and nonsensical solution by his colleague—and, I dare say friend, the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), his rival for the leadership of the national left faction. So plainly there are just no answers on the other side of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am on the national left, am I?

—You tell me, Martin. I do not want to spend too much time on the contribution of the member for Banks (Mr Melham). He accused the government of going back to the old days. Of course, it was the member for Melbourne who accused many members opposite of wanting to go waltzing down memory lane, hand in hand with Pauline Hanson. It was the member for Banks who talked about the former government bringing the nation together and not dividing communities. Even the member for Banks surely must find the suggestion of the former Prime Minister—Mr Keating—as some kind of great conciliator, some great healing figure, slightly ludicrous. Let us face it, the former Prime Minister was the man who regularly denounced people in this very building as unrepresentative swill, and so on.
—He never came from the back. He always came from the front, which is more than can be said for—

—I do want to make a few comments, prompted by the remarks of the member for Banks and I will continue these comments in a moment. In particular, I want to comment on his remark that the policy that the government has adopted on Abstudy is in some way the creation of my former adviser. My former adviser had no policy role whatsoever and has had absolutely nothing to do with any policy proposals since we came to government—but I will continue this in a moment. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —What the government is saying to us in relation to unemployment is: give us more time. Unemployment has gone from 8.5 per cent when we left office to 8.8 per cent now and the government says: give us more time. Given that when John Howard was Treasurer, he left us with unemployment at 10 per cent, does that mean that the electorate ought to give him time to bring unemployment up from 8.5 through 8.8 to 10 per cent? Plainly, the government has no answers in relation to unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: They have said `Give us our industrial relations legislation.' They have said, `Let us cut the budget. Let us implement all the reforms that we want to do.' Then they look around and say, `Oh dear, unemployment has gone up. What are we going to do about it now? Are we going to introduce a GST?' It is always, `Give us our agenda and then something will happen in relation to unemployment.' In fact, they have no answers in relation to unemployment. It is particularly severe in regional areas, with 12.9 per cent in Gippsland and 12.9 per cent in other areas of rural Victoria.

The thing that I particularly want to put before the committee in consideration in detail is the future of the skillshares. I and other members have received correspondence from skillshares about where they will be left in this brave new employment services market world. The National Skillshare Association has pointed out:

. . . in the event that the government does not provide the advance payments we are seeking, the great majority of our more than 350 community organisation members will not be in a position to submit tenders for this important element of the new market. The inevitable consequence of this would be that many would be forced to cease operations altogether, with associated loss of valuable community infrastructure and dimunition of capacity, diversity and competition in the proposed market—particularly in terms of provision of assistance to the most disadvantaged unemployed people. We think it not unreasonable that the Government should set conditions for initial operation of the new market which recognise the particular and special circumstances of not‐for‐profit organisations and which give them a reasonable chance to adapt to the competitive environment the Government intends to create.
We have had correspondence from the National Skillshare Association to the minister which says:

Our own analysis of the financial parameters for providing employment assistance services under the terms set out in the Exposure Draft make it clear that even the most optimistic assumptions about client flows and outcomes achieved will still see organisations facing significant negative cash flows in the early stages of the operation of the market.
They go on to say:

It is entirely unreasonable for the government or the department to expect that the good citizens who comprise the Boards and Management Committees of sponsor organisations should expose themselves to the significant additional burdens and personal financial risks associated with borrowing funds so they can continue . . .

Similarly, Mr Deputy Speaker, we had correspondence from the Maylands skillshare. This is a Western Australian skillshare but it reflects the situation found by skillshares in my electorate and in other parts of the country that were set up by non‐profit organisations. Maylands was set up by the Royal Western Australian Institute for the Blind. They point out that after February 1998 they will experience negative cash flows for at least three months until payments for the employment services provided are made.

They say that, having had to operate as not‐for‐profit organisations, skillshares do not have any cash reserves, let alone substantial ones. It is little surprise against that background that the Royal Western Australian Institute for the Blind has made the decision that it is unable to underwrite the temporary negative cash flow—at this stage estimated to be in the range of $45,000 to $70,000—and this leads to a scenario of the pin being pulled on Maylands skillshare. As they point out, it will be repeated with many skillshare organisations all around Australia.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I and a number of other members of parliament have also received correspondence from the north‐east employment project where they have talked about Dr David Kemp's plan to spend $200 million on school based employment programs. They pose this question: is there any way in which Dr Kemp might be persuaded that effective, efficient not‐for‐ profit organisations already exist, at least in Victoria, to do exactly the job for which he proposes reinventing the wheel?

That is exactly right. The abandonment of the CES—or the carve‐up of the CES—in my view will lead to a disaster in terms of employment placement at the very time this community can least afford it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott, Tony, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take up the member's point about skillshare. The government has a great deal of respect for the skillshare sector and my understanding is that negotiations are taking place between the skillshare sector and the department on the sorts of transitional issues that he raised.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to go back briefly to the question raised by the member for Banks (Mr Melham) and the role of my former adviser. My former adviser left me on Friday 9 May and the following Monday he appeared as the chief adviser to the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). I have to say that I regarded that as an act of treachery. I regarded that as an act of betrayal of me, of the local Liberal Party which gave him an enormous amount of support as the preselected candidate for Manly, and of a great many citizens of Manly who had reposed their trust and confidence in him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was he in your faction?

—As a matter of fact, if we had factions in the Liberal Party—and we do not—he would have been in the other faction. It was, if you like, as a way of handing an olive branch to others that he entered my office.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The parliamentary secretary will be heard in silence.

—After he left my employ, I asked for a check to be made of his mobile phone calls. It became apparent that he had made dozens of phone calls on a departmental mobile phone, going back to late last year, to the member for Oxley and to David Ettridge. Obviously, these had absolutely nothing whatsoever to do with his duties as my staff member. They had absolutely nothing to do with his role in helping to liaise between the department and me. I wrote two letters to the departmental secretary seeking the investigation of those phone calls and seeking the recovery of any costs that were incurred that were not properly attributable to his work for me. I believe that those investigations are continuing.

SPEECH.PARA: Not long after he left my office, I was contacted by David Thomas, a former employee of the member for Oxley, who let me know that while my former staffer was employed by me he had attended some functions which again had absolutely nothing to do with his employment by me or his work in liaising with the department, but had everything to do with the moonlighting he had been doing for the member for Oxley.

I have also written to the Department of Administrative Services seeking an investigation of one trip and one section of another trip, because again I am absolutely determined to ensure that no costs will be incurred by the taxpayers for activities which helped to enable my former staffer to assist the member for Oxley.

Obviously, the behaviour of my former staffer is hugely embarrassing for me and for the local Liberal Party, but it is also a real problem for the member for Oxley. The member for Oxley has taken onto her staff someone with so little sense of propriety, someone with so little sense of discretion about the use of government resources that he was prepared to use those government resources quite freely in ways which had nothing to do with his work for me as the member for Warringah, nothing to do with his work for the electors of Warringah, and nothing whatsoever to do with his work for the department.

In fact, information provided by David Thomas suggests that not only did he do this when he was working for me but now that he is working for the member for Oxley, even though he is employed by her in her capacity as an independent member of parliament, he is working full‐time on the establishment of the One Nation Party. This strikes me as being at odds with the spirit, if not the letter, of the provisions under which independent members get an extra staff entitlement.

There are some very serious issues for the member for Oxley here. She preaches restraint in the use of government funds, but it is hard to see that it is being practised. So far, the member for Oxley, as an independent, looks to resemble Senator Colston more than she does Ted Mack.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the things of substance that has not emerged in this discussion about these changes to support for young unemployed people is what they will do in terms of the shift between public and private education. The truth is that you inject large numbers of people into an education system where they know they are going to get no benefit, save that that is their only means of having income support and the only way in which their families can sustain their children with any form of commitment. The unemployment circumstances are such that they cannot find employment and this government is going to refuse them the opportunities to seek employment and to improve their employability through labour market programs or access to unemployment benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: If you force those unwilling participants into an already overcrowded state education system, then people will naturally say that that will degrade that state education system. They will not be going into private education because they do not have the means. The only sector of the education system they will be able to access is the already overcrowded and underfunded state education system. That will then carry the baggage of unwilling participants. Teachers will be baby‐sitting large numbers of people who will be getting no benefit and whose parents know they are getting no benefit. Those who wish to participate to gain benefit out of the education system will increasingly have to choose to fund their children's education in the private sector.

As well as the natural damage that is occurring to Australia's families, we will get the pressure that this will place on family breakdown and the consequences it will mean for the impoverishment of many families who will not wish to force their children into this stupid position. As well as that, we will find that it will degrade the state education systems around Australia. Years 11 and 12 will be carrying unwilling, unwelcome participants. They will be therefore unattractive to people who have the funds to escape from those systems. They will move into the private education system. Increasingly, we get a two‐tier system of education where you get quality education only if you pay for it. Of course, that is being matched with a funding regime that increasingly benefits those newly established independent schools. Schools will be established in places where there is no check that they will not damage the participation of the public educational sector and where the transfer costs, as they emerge, will gut the effectiveness of the public education system.

What we are actually doing is trying to hide unemployment. This government is trying to hide unemployment by shifting it into forcing people into years 11 and 12 education when we, as the former government, had already increased participation to a degree which was hitherto unknown in Australia. We were actually getting people going through higher education. Now we will force unwilling participants, who will not be capable of benefiting from it, into that system. That will degrade that public education system. It will continue the transfer and shift of people out of public education into private education. A class‐ridden outcome, where wealth dictates your success in life, emerges as the likely outcome.

That is what you can predict as a result of these very stupid changes. The only motivating factor that underlies them is a desire to obscure the fact that this government has nothing to offer to young Australians, who they bleated about before the last election as being their object of primary concern. Before the last election, the high rate of unemployed in that sector who were not participating in the education system was identified as this government's number one priority.

BREAK.PARA: What do they do in government? They turn on those very people. They offer them no employment opportunities. They offer them no effective training opportunities. They park them in an educational system for which they cannot gain a benefit because that system is not designed to operate as a technical or further education system. It is not designed to increase job readiness. They will park them there, they will degrade that system's effectiveness, and they will increase the shift of people from the public sector to the private sector. This is retrograde and stupid as far as Australia's national interests are concerned. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to the most recent intervention by the parliamentary secretary and I can understand his feelings about treachery with respect to his former assistant, Mr Oldfield. He has raised very serious allegations today going to the operation of the parliament and the system of assistance, both to government and to the opposition, with respect to their staff. In that context, it is exceptionally important that he actually tables the correspondence that he has sent to the department setting out his allegations, so that the parliament at large and the Australian public understand the types of allegations he has detailed and required the department to investigate.

SPEECH.PARA: It is only fair because I think that there is a genuine desire on both sides of the House at the moment to ensure full and proper parliamentary accountability with respect to the use of parliamentary entitlements. In that context, I fully appreciate why the parliamentary secretary is, if anything, really a little bit emotional with respect to these issues. I would feel the same way if it had occurred to me. So, I suggest that today, or at some date that is possible, the details of the allegations as set out in his correspondence be tabled because I think the parliament wants to know what is really at the bottom of this. The allegations that he has made today do not just go to his own staff; they also go to the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson).

I also want to touch briefly on questions raised by the parliamentary secretary relating to an overall budget strategy. I appreciate that there is no quick‐fix on the issue of jobs. It is fair to say that both houses have different approaches but, from the Labor Party's point of view, it is appropriate that we detail what we regard as an appropriate strategy. It is a debate about ideas and not a question of a bottomless pit and throwing money at the unemployed. It goes to your capacity to generate economic growth—and I point the finger and suggest that a projected level of economic growth of 3.5 per cent is inadequate. That is not just my view; it is also the view of the Reserve Bank governor and the secretary of Treasury.

I also suggest that economic growth alone is not necessary. It goes to government policy and to whether you have industry and regional policy—and I am pleased to say that the government actually embraced our automotive plan. We have paved the way and forced reform at an international level with respect to the globalisation of the economy and changes, for example, on the tariff front. But enough was enough. It was appropriate that both sides of the House came together on the Labor Party's industry plan for the automotive industry.

But it extends beyond the automotive industry to a range of other industries. It then goes to the question of regional Australia. You need to intervene and assist in regional Australia. It also raises the question of services to regional Australia. If you care about jobs, it is not smart to sack 28,000 public servants in the first two budgets.

That takes me to the final aspect of a program, having touched on briefly the issue of a trade policy. We have a pool of long‐term unemployed. Unfortunately, more and more of those people are in particular suburbs and regions. You have to have targeted decent labour market programs that you are prepared to invest in to try and get those people job ready, back into the discipline of work and back to work. We are prepared to debate the ideas. There is no quick‐fix, but you have got to have a strategy.

The problem with this government, I dare to suggest, is that it does not have a job strategy. It has a mind‐set which extends beyond a role for government actually intervening and getting its hands dirty. It should be trying to facilitate, to push and prod, to attract investment, to create jobs and also to deliver those vital labour market programs that are so important to get people back into the discipline of work so that they have a capacity to change employers' attitudes to ensure that the employers finally accept that those people who could have been forgotten are worthy of employment. That is what it is about. We should not push them aside and forget them. We have to intervene and assist and invest in their future. They are worthy of employment; they deserve a second go.

Green Corps is wrong. The majority of places have gone to people in employment and/or education. Our responsibility—that is, the responsibility of the parliament as a whole, irrespective of policy differences—is to accept that there is a role for government in assisting those people. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had a full debate on these issues, and I thank members opposite for their contributions. I would like to indicate that, as far as the government is concerned, the debate has canvassed the issues adequately. Finally, on the matters raised concerning the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson), yes, she does have an important challenge to demonstrate just what kind of an independent member she is in respect of her attitude to public funds. Yes, on the suggestions before us, she may resemble Mal Colston more than she resembles Ted Mack. I want to say that the matters are being investigated. They are serious matters and, when those investigations are concluded, an appropriate statement will be made. I can give the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) that assurance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will follow up on a couple of matters that emerged in relation to the comments of the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott). It is not merely a matter, I would suggest, of referring matters in relation to the former employee for investigation and assessment. This is analogous to the situation that emerged in West Germany before East and West Germany merged, where it was discerned that Willy Brandt, when Chancellor, had had on his staff as one of his closest advisers a person who was working for and reporting to the East German authorities. When that fact was discerned, it was a matter not merely of how that had come to occur, what responsibility there was and what prosecution or action could be taken against that former employee who had betrayed the trust, but also of how the supervision and the character judgment of Willy Brandt was such as to have allowed that person to remain in that office for such a period of time and to carry on that activity under the nose of a person in Brandt's position.

SPEECH.PARA: There are questions that actually go to Parliamentary Secretary Abbott's capacity, responsibility, supervision and management of his office. There is also the question of the degree to which he, ministers, other parliamentary secretaries and other members of the coalition parties may in fact have contributed to the situation through their failure to scrutinise the work that was being undertaken and also the character of, and the nature of the responsibilities being pursued by, people in their employment who were actually working for a social force that has properly been characterised now by the Prime Minister as analogous to the kind of disruptive force that has emerged in other countries to the great detriment of their social cohesion. That situation was occurring under the watch of the parliamentary secretary, and we do not know whether similar practices are occurring with respect to any other coalition members, parliamentary secretaries or ministers.

This goes also to a further question relating to the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). If she was knowingly the beneficiary of work that was being performed by somebody who was on the payroll of another member of parliament, and if she was drawing from that a benefit to which she was not entitled, that is plainly analogous to a form of corruption of the process. It is a form of corruption because it goes to taking that which you know you are not entitled to—by reason of the fact that it was being paid for in order to be supportive of, in this case, the parliamentary secretary at the table. It is analogous to drawing from another member of parliament part of their postal entitlement or any other entitlement to which you yourself are not entitled. So, there are questions that go to the knowledge and the participation of those in the office of the member for Oxley. Those are fundamentally important questions.

Has the parliamentary secretary asked that those matters also be pursued? If not, why not? Why have those matters not been sought to be put to the test? I would also ask the parliamentary secretary why his judgment of the character of those working for him was so remiss. What steps did he put in place to select people who were fit to occupy the office that he entrusted them to hold within his staff? It is not a matter you can brush off by saying, `These people betrayed me.' From what the parliamentary secretary has indicated to date, there plainly was a long history of deceit.

What was it that was so slack about his management of his office? What steps are in place to ensure that this does not happen in other circumstances where there may be people who are actually letting down those who have placed trust in them? What are the staffing processes that those in ministerial and other executive positions, including parliamentary secretaries, undertake to make certain that they are not appointing people to positions of high responsibility who will, as occurred in Germany, betray them. When that occurred in Germany, the criticism fell on Willy Brandt for his failure to manage his office, as much as it did on the betrayal of those on his staff. There are two questions there: what were the circumstances whereby your scrutiny of your own office was so deficient; and, secondly, what steps, if any, have you asked to be undertaken with respect to the member for Oxley's participation? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott, Tony, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Denison (Mr Kerr) does raise two important issues. The sad truth is that it is impossible to control what members of one's staff do in their own time and outside of one's own office. I think I can give the chamber an assurance that none of the misdeeds of my former staff member took place in my office, certainly not in office hours, for the simple reason that it is an open plan office and anything untoward would immediately have been noticed by the other staff members who were sitting around him. The misdeeds took place out of the office and on the mobile phone, to the best of my knowledge, and I think I can reasonably make the assumption that that is the case.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Denison also says, `How on earth could I have possibly employed this person?' Yes, that is also a fair question. All I say in my defence is that this individual was able to persuade a majority of a Liberal Party preselection panel—and it was not in a hard luck seat which no‐one wants to run in, like Oxley, but a state seat which was traditionally a Liberal seat. It was a hotly contested preselection, he emerged victorious and I guess I took the view that anyone who was good enough for the Liberal Party at that level would probably be an appropriate person for me. He was also a member of Manly Council, elected by the people of Manly. So I think I had reasonable grounds for assuming that the man was competent, capable and trustworthy. Certainly there is no denying his competence. It is just that what he did while in my office over the last few months of his employment was an act of treachery.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would remind the House that any questions in relation to a particular staff member whose salary was not covered by the estimates under debate would need to be relevant to the issues before the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —To enable this matter to conclude, may I raise the issue of what process does apply with respect to character checks of staff being employed by the executive? As minister for justice under the former government, I am aware, because I had some managerial and supervisory role in relation to this, that staff were required to be vetted not merely by those who recommended their appointment in the first place but ultimately, including when security issues and other issues were of concern, by officers of ASIO, for example, in relation to security vetting.

SPEECH.PARA: These were checks that were built into the employment system. I acknowledge, with respect to the former government, that there were occasions between the appointment process and the completion of those checks when those vetting processes were not taking place. But those checks would deal with associates and a whole range of other issues and would go to character and a whole associated raft of issues. I wonder whether, if not necessarily now, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Mr Abbott) could take on notice whether or not those same arrangements still apply, and, if not, what arrangements are in place to ensure that mistakes are not made simply because somebody has a seemingly good public reputation yet may have participated in a way which could ultimately be very damaging to the interests of the Commonwealth of Australia.

This is simply an interest where your political interests have been damaged significantly because of that betrayal. But, potentially, a failure to assess the character and fitness for service of an employee of the executive could have much more significant security and other national consequences were that betrayal not to another political party but, for example, to another nation. I simply ask that that question be addressed.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that the same kinds of vetting processes are in place now as were in place under the former government.

—I rise because I was incited to by the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) in relation to this debate and in terms of employment. The government's forecast of economic growth in the budget is at 3.75 per cent. It is that that concerns me with the government's attitude and the parliamentary secretary's attitude, `Let's have a bit of patience. Let's wait, things will get better,' but 3.75 per cent growth is not enough to pick up newcomers to the marketplace into job opportunities. In our last couple of years of government we exceeded those growth rates. That is why this government piggybacked in on young people's fear of job opportunities that they thought were vanishing. They were looking forward to a government that had promised them that they would address the issue of youth unemployment.

BREAK.PARA: What we have had is a government in the last 15 months that is like a rabbit under the spotlight. They do not know which way to jump; they are frozen. We have had a number of interest rate cuts and the government says, `Oh, isn't this terrific.' The interest rate cuts that have occurred are a vote of no confidence in this government. They are interest cuts that have occurred because the economy is comatose. It is like a corpse and the interest rate cuts have been applied by the Reserve Bank to try and breathe life back into the economy, to try and kickstart building opportunities, housing opportunities and to create work opportunities. That of itself is not going to be enough to bring down the levels of unemployment.

It is the budget figures themselves that are the cause for doom and gloom on my part and on the parts of other commentators. This government is not addressing this issue and it will not get better. They have a hands‐off approach—the previous Labor government had a hands‐on approach. We had a situation where there were external factors that affected unemployment. I can remember making my first speech in September 1990 and talking about the 1.7 million jobs that were created by the Labor Party until that time. That is when unemployment went bad as a result of external factors and other factors such as the TCF policy, the lowering of tariff barriers.

This government has the opportunity to learn from some of those mistakes. But what do they do? It is a hands‐off approach. The only intervention that this government engages in is intervention against indigenous Australians. Instead of allowing the marketplace to rule and the rule of law and the Native Title Act that allows miners and Aborigines the right to negotiate, they want to intervene to take away the limited rights that the High Court gave them. They are interventionists against Aborigines, but they are not interventionists when it comes to creating job opportunities.

That is the problem—the budget figures nail the lie, they nail the myth. Employment opportunities are not going to get better under this government. The growth is not enough. That is why you need intervention. The very areas that are suffering are the areas that voted for you overwhelmingly. Regional Australia is haemorrhaging—it is bleeding. Towns are closing. You cannot take away the tax office and all these other offices and you cannot rip 28,000 public servants out of the system and expect the system to pick up the slack. There is a multiplier effect, a knock‐on effect. That is why people now are starting to get alarmed. They are still reserving their judgment because there is enormous goodwill out there for this government. But when it sinks in that what has happened is a betrayal of the hopes and aspirations that were promised to them in the lead‐up to the last election, that is when you will see the shift. But that is of no comfort to regional Australia.

You do need labour market programs. Working Nation was a successful program. The training programs were beneficial. Money spent on skillshare in my area saw 65 and 70 per cent outcomes in terms of job opportunities for people. Skillshare is a successful organisation. It has a great track record. You should be encouraging it. You should be opening up skillshare offices, not closing them down. I lost a CES in my area: that is what is happening. There is no future under this government for young people, or for anyone else, and time will show that to be true. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In debating the estimates for this portfolio and especially in the discussions concerning unemployment, there is a need to stress the locational disparity of the unemployment figures. That needs to be stressed to this government because it does not seem to acknowledge that that is the case. It is not only the absolute figures that we are concerned with, the fact that there has been an inability by the government to reduce unemployment, but also the fact that on a regional basis, as has been outlined by the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), in areas such as rural Victoria there has been increasing unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: If you look at the unemployment figures in a region like mine, which I share with the member for Batman and the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), and although the figures are not sufficiently disaggregated easily, we know that long‐term unemployment is increasing. Traditionally, in a region like the north-eastern suburbs of Melbourne, that has been a factor within the unemployment figures, that the long‐term unemployed in the region that we represent is great. Also, if you look at the figures that are supplied by the Bureau of Statistics you will see that in the north-eastern suburbs of Melbourne that female unemployment has increased by a large amount recently.

What I am trying to do by highlighting those factors is get the government to understand that it just cannot have a broad brush approach to the problems of unemployment. I also want to say that those programs that have not yet wound down, and those programs that are applauded by people like the Minister for Schools (Dr Kemp), are targeting areas where there is already a good labour market. They do not target areas where there are disadvantaged, unemployed people.

You find that when you have things like the pathways programs going into schools, that that has been targeted to areas where it is for the easy outcomes. It is in areas where the labour market is in a more healthy condition than it is in other areas. There appears to be this tendency to put the programs in where they can get the easy mark. There does not appear to be a willingness to develop programs that are going to attack unemployment in regional areas such as the north-eastern suburbs of Melbourne.

There the problems of unemployment have been very severe for a long time, and there the problems have been exacerbated by the opening up of the economy to international factors. Things like tariff reductions have already had a dramatic effect there. That is why schemes like special assistance to people involved in the passenger motor vehicle industry and in TCF were so important.

In the area I represent we had both those industries as major employers. The dramatic effects of tariff reductions have been felt, and there is a need to target those people who are losing jobs in those industries. That is a feature that over the last year and a bit we have lost. This government is unable to understand that we should be maximising outcomes to ensure that unlike the United Kingdom and unlike the United States we do not see this continuing marginalisation of large areas of the nation. That is what will happen unless we attack and target areas of greatest disadvantage.

If we do not have that as one of our primary reasons for putting in place programs it will lead to the same problems of social dislocation and all the other matters that we see highlighted in countries such as the United Kingdom and the United States. I implore the ministers and the parliamentary secretary, who has been good enough to stay for this long debate, to have a look at these matters. They are important, and the government needs to be looking at ways in which it can at least give hope to people who are finding it difficult to find employment, and to areas that are going to be in even more difficulty unless they get this type of assistance.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Proposed expenditure, $786,701,000

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Since first coming to this place I have been very conscious of the need to lend my support to try to simplify or change federal laws or regulations that are inappropriate, unworkable or not working the way they were intended. Although this first matter perhaps pertains to the Treasurer's portfolio I want to mention that, and I have stated this before, the laws in relation to child support are the worst examples of legislation that can truly be called an ass, and I am sure a majority of members would agree with me.

SPEECH.PARA: Why haven't we reformed the punitive, mentally destroying formula for setting non‐custodial payments? They are cruel and destructive in many cases, and I am sure other members would have cases on their files and would agree. It is an absolute disgrace that the previous government and now this one have not treated reform of this area with the urgency it deserves.

We talk about making apologies for the stolen children episode of our history, and yet here today we have a federal act that is causing similar pain and disruption to many families—particularly children—and no apparent sense of urgency to introduce meaningful reform. While child support legislation, in my mind, is the most urgent in need of serious reform, number two, as far as complaints go during my relatively short time in this place, would have to be problems in relation to the Copyright Act 1968, and the way it is being mercilessly exploited by the Australian Performing Rights Association, or APRA.

This is a problem that other members and I have raised on numerous occasions with the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) and he has indicated reforms are possible but, as far as I am concerned, as with child support, the changes cannot come soon enough. APRA has embarked on an aggressive revenue collecting campaign over the past 18 months, based on a fact that a court ruled that the inside of a business could be regarded as a public place. APRA is now threatening businesses all over Australia that it will take them to court unless they pay licence fees to have a radio on in their premises.

Let me give members an example. I recently visited a small butcher shop at Yeoval up in the top end of my electorate run by a young man in his 20s. You could not really begin to imagine, Mr Deputy Speaker, how lonely this job is in a small place like that. I called in on a Tuesday about lunch time. This young man had had two customers through his doors that morning. The only company he had was the local radio. The week before he had been sent one of those threatening letters from APRA saying that his radio was a public performance of music and that he would be taken to court unless he paid the annual copyright exemption fee, which I would suggest was a darn sight more than that small butcher made in profits during that particular day.

As this young man pointed out, the radio was not on to entertain the public. It was there solely for his personal benefit. So small was his business that he did not have meat out in the display fridge, he had little signs with the prices for `short loin chops' and `sausages' spread out for the people coming into the shop. It was not worth his while to cut the pieces off and put them on show. He had to cut the meat to order from that he had in the coolroom. The amount of income made by a small retailer in a little village like Yeoval is minimal and these APRA fees represent an unreasonable impost.

I raised the issue with the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) last year. His reply to my representations showed an alarming lack of interest in the issue. The Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) has shown a deal more interest, and I appreciate the problems he faces. The story of the butcher at Yeoval, however, is but one of no doubt hundreds of examples from around Australia of how small business is suffering.

I have taken the trouble to visit APRA headquarters in Sydney. I have heard their story. I realise our international understandings and obligations but, as the case of the Yeoval butcher shows, the system is unfair. Obviously there is double‐dipping of performing rights, given that the radio stations already pay substantial rights for playing the record. I have no problem with the performing rights for music played for commercial gain in gyms, for example, but the system is unfair and it is penalising business in my electorate, and no doubt elsewhere.

I ask the Attorney‐General to revisit this particular piece of legislation urgently. I also hope he passes on to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, the need to do something urgently about the Child Support Act. Those Senate reforms have been sitting around for a couple of years now and they must be addressed with haste, because some people out there are almost suicidal and their lives have been destroyed by the impost that that act places on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am thankful that the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) is here because I have a couple of questions to ask him. There are only 11 days to go before the end of the financial year. I would like to know, and I am sure the House would like to know, what is happening to the legal aid agreements. A $120 million budget cut was imposed in the Attorney‐General's Department. SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, the Attorney‐General and the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) were working away to try to resolve the problem, and then the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) went on the Laurie Oakes Sunday program. He was not properly briefed. He said, `No, we are not going to change what we are doing.' I understand that a proposal was going to go back to the cabinet to remedy the situation, because they were acting on old figures and a few misconceptions. However, as a result of the stubbornness of the Prime Minister, legal aid is in crisis.

This is a great tragedy for me. I am a product of the legal aid system. I was only in private practice for three months and then I was proud to go to work as a public solicitor in New South Wales from 1979 to 1987, when I received appointment as a public defender. I worked as a public defender in New South Wales from October 1987 until February 1990, when I had to resign to run for public office because it was an office of profit. I have a commitment to legal aid.

Legal aid cannot cover the field—it is there in partnership with the private profession—but the former Labor government looked after legal aid. When Labor came into office in 1983, the Fraser government had turned the Australian Legal Aid Office, which was a creation of the Whitlam Labor government, into a referral factory. There were discussions with all the states and territories. There was a merging of the Australian Legal Aid Office in New South Wales with the New South Wales Legal Aid Commission. An efficient system was then operating.

That was repeated around the country. There was a one‐stop shop and there was a Commonwealth‐state arrangement. Then the bean counters got in. A lot of people do not understand what the definition of a Commonwealth offence is. Have we worked out what the definition of a Commonwealth offence is and what a state offence is? New South Wales has decided, in effect, to go it alone.

BREAK.PARA: What has happened with Western Australia? We are told that the federal government has yet to make an offer to Western Australia with 11 days to go. I ask the Attorney‐General: what is the current situation? There are only 11 days to go. Legal aid is in crisis in this country. I understand the pressures on the Attorney‐General and the bean counters, but what has happened to the legal system, with the increase in court fees and a whole host of things, is a disgrace. And I know it is currently being debated in the Senate.

Access to justice now is a myth. It is the rich or the infinitely poor that are able to access the system of justice Even then it is a question of whether the poor can access it, because people on pensions are missing out on a whole range of things. This is what is happening at the coalface. This is what disillusioned people who work in the system are telling me. If it was not for the goodwill of a lot of people working in the system, who are carrying the system by working extra hours, the system would be in total collapse.

My question to the Attorney‐General is: what is the state of play? I know that you have to run the government line and these decisions are not solely your own, but I would like to know the current situation with all the states and territories. What is happening as of 1 July? What agreements have been signed up? What has not been signed up? What are the provisions in the Commonwealth area where there have not been agreements signed. I think we need to know. I am not holding him personally responsible. I know the pressures he is under but, in the end, he has to carry the can. That is what ministerial responsibility is about. In the end, he is the spokesperson. Have I got it wrong? Have the states given us wrong information? What is the situation? (Time expired)
