SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Banks (Mr Melham) has raised a question of what is happening with legal aid. He asserted that legal aid is in crisis, let me assure him that it is not and let me assure him that the expectation of the government is that there will be arrangements in place on 1 July with all jurisdictions which will enable a delivery by legal aid commissions of state and federal funds for legal aid in each jurisdiction.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of announcements have already been made in relation to individual jurisdictions. In respect of the Northern Territory, the ACT and South Australia, it was some time ago announced that in principle, agreement had been reached with each of those jurisdictions for the continuation of a cooperative delivery through the legal aid or legal service commissions of those jurisdictions.

In respect of Queensland and New South Wales, it has already been announced that in principle, agreement has been reached with those jurisdictions on the delivery of Commonwealth funds for legal aid through the state legal aid commissions but on an agency or funder provider basis. In the case of Victoria, there has been an announcement made that there will be a combination of the cooperative and the agency arrangements made, initially the cooperative arrangement and then the agency arrangement.

Negotiations with the two remaining jurisdictions, Tasmania and Western Australia, have progressed well. In fact, with one of them, the negotiations are effectively complete. With the other there is still some detail in relation to guidelines to be determined but we anticipate that the requirements will be met in respect of both those jurisdictions in time for a 1 July commencement of new agreements.

The member for Banks made some comments about the budget cuts. Let me just say that the government policy is to eliminate budget deficits. One of the problems we have with the inability of the economy in recent years to maintain economic growth on a sustainable basis has been caused by the government debt generating foreign debt as a result of budget deficits and the government has turned around the budgetary situation such that the $10.5 billion deficit that it inherited for the year 1995‐96 will, by the year 1988‐99, be converted into a surplus. In other words, from a major deficit, through three budgets, there will be a surplus.

In respect to legal aid, let me mention that legal aid is not the only item on the access to justice agenda. Community legal centres are increasingly an important source of legal advice and access to justice for individual citizens. There are some 115 of those organisations funded under the Commonwealth budget and funding for them, subject to the indexing, both upwards and downwards—efficiency dividend on the one hand and the CPI indexing on the other—has been maintained, and in excess of $15 million in the current year's budget has provided for CLCs.

In addition, you do not need legal aid money from Legal Aid Commissions to be able to obtain legal advice. In any event, legal advice itself is not necessarily the best means of resolving a dispute. In that vein, the government has recently provided some $6 million over three years for 34 new services. (Extension of time granted) I am indebted to the member for Banks and to you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I was talking about mediation and counselling services. It has been demonstrated very well that people who receive relationship education are much less likely to be divorced than people who do not. In fact, those who receive pre‐marriage counselling, or are the recipients of education services, have a very low rate of divorce. It may, in part, reflect the fact that those who seek that sort of advice are less likely to be unable to resolve conflicts that might arise in a relationship. But the fact is that it seems to be effective, we ought to be expanding it, and this government is expanding it. That means that there is less call on agencies like the Family Court.

We are seeking to have mediation and counselling focused in community organisations where it is much more available and can be delivered much more inexpensively. That in itself provides access to justice, looked at in a broad way. What we are doing is preventing the need for money to be applied at the wrong end and applying money in an effective way at the front end. So the access to justice story is a bigger one and needs to be looked at.

On legal aid itself, let me just add a couple of comments. There has been a major reform of the legal aid delivery system, resulting from the renegotiation of the agreements. The result is likely to be that there will be measures introduced by legal aid commissions, such as those that have been introduced by Victorian legal aid. There will be some categories of cases which will not be funded. That is appropriate. There will be some categories of cases where there will be funding cuts. That also is appropriate. Victorian legal aid has been criticised for imposing a $10,000 limit on partners and a $15,000 on separate representation of children for resolving issues relating to children, that is, residence or contact issues in relation to a particular family.

An amount of $35,000 to enable parties to organise a separation seems to me to be more than adequate. If there is an impetus on the part of the lawyers to resolve the matter within that sort of fee cap, there will be correspondingly an impetus for the parties to be a bit more reasonable and not to seek to extend hearings in the Family Court unnecessarily.

There has been a lack of application of the notion that legally aided clients should not receive assistance in excess of that received by or available to a person who is funding himself or herself. What we want to do in the guidelines is to ensure that the principle of provision of legal aid to legally assisted clients is limited to the sort of assistance that would be likely to be provided at their own expense by an ordinarily prudent self‐funding litigant.

The member for Denison (Mr Kerr) has raised a number of questions and, in order to answer those questions in some detail, I would need to take them on notice. Let me offer some broad comment, however. In relation to the Australian Federal Police, the only impact in the current budget on the Australian Federal Police is the efficiency dividend. I cannot tell him precisely what the impact of that may be on staff. I can assure him there is no area of policy responsibility that will be eliminated. But, in his former capacity as minister for justice, he would be well aware that the AFP, like other law enforcement agencies, is unable to investigate every complaint that is made to it. (Extension of time granted) The member for Denison would be well aware of the need by the AFP, like other law enforcement agencies, to prioritise the matters to be investigated. The system that was put in place under the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Review in broad terms remains in place for that purpose.

As far as overseas postings are concerned, it is my understanding that there will not be any overseas liaison officers currently in place removed. Without additional funding, it may be difficult to expand the overseas liaison service, but that presently in existence will remain. Those officers are in fact providing a very valuable service. In many cases they operate within one country, but have dealings with a number of others. The officers in Thailand, for example, regularly visit Vietnam and have contact with the liaison officers in Hong Kong who in turn deal with China.

As far as the NCA is concerned, again in the current budget there is no cut to the NCA other than the efficiency dividend. But in addition the NCA will, as a result of a new initiative, receive over four years an amount of $20.4 million for a special project in relation to fraud against the Commonwealth. It is anticipated that this will bring in significant revenue to the Commonwealth amounting to some $60 million potentially in tax that would otherwise be uncollected and $30 million in anticipated recoveries of the proceeds of crime as well. Far from cutting staff under the current budget, the NCA will in fact be able to place additional staff in Perth and Adelaide, among other places. I have seen different figures, but I understand it may be up to about six officers in Perth and up to four officers in Adelaide.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is alleged by the member for Denison to have suffered the biggest budget cut of any agency. In fact it has not. It has only suffered the efficiency dividend, like all other agencies, in the current budget. What he presumably is referring to is the anticipated cut in next year's budget which is contained in the forward estimates—an amount of $4.3 million to come off the budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an effective 40 per cent cut.

—No, it is not an effective 40 per cent cut. If you look at the figure from 1997‐98 to 1998‐99, it is 27 per cent. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, in its current form, was established under the 1986 act. Since then, it has grown from a budget of about $5 million in 1986‐87 or 1987‐88, I forget which, to a budget that at one point exceeded $20 million. It has grown from a staff of approximately 50 in that 1986‐87 period to a staff that at one point exceeded 220.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened is that each time a new function has been given to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission they have been in effect given a new funding arrangement and, regrettably, a new commissioner. So we now have a commission which comprises a president and six commissioners, each of whom has something that operates, in practical terms, as a separate budget. Attempts by the previous government to achieve a more corporate structure through a review of the commission failed because the review officers failed to agree on a report. Two members were prepared to sign the report, another member was not prepared to sign it.

In a time when money is in short supply and there is a necessity to bring the budget into balance or surplus, the funding available to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is, in general terms, more than adequate and it is appropriate that there be a significant cut to the budget. The commission is expected, in consequence, to run a more efficient ship, to run a ship that is administered corporately. There is in fact being debated today a bill which will enable some reform of the commission to take place. The effect would be to transfer complaint processing to a full‐time president, taking it out of the hands of the individual commissioners. The commissioners would then be able to focus to a greater extent upon the portfolio responsibilities in their own areas, but principally in the education area, which I suspect has suffered somewhat through the need for the individual commissioners to be involved in the conciliation of complaints.

I am sure that the commission will be able to live within its budget and still achieve much that is expected of it by the community. But, like every other agency in the government, it has to live within the government's means. That will mean that there will be some cost cutting. It will also mean that some things that the individual commissioners might like to do will not be able to be done. But hopefully it will mean that individual commissioners, together with the president, will decide on what are the priority areas for action, rather than leaving it to individual commissioners to engage in personal interests.

The Administrative Review Council report Better decisions has been considered by cabinet. The member for Denison is probably aware that an announcement has been made that the cabinet in principle accepted the recommendations of that report and established a interdepartmental committee to consider how the recommendations might be implemented.

I have seen with some interest the article under the name of Roderick Campbell in the Canberra Times last Monday, 16 June, and I am interested to see how what is suggested there would be consistent with the cabinet decision. Plainly, it is not. But let us not attempt to speculate on what cabinet might decide when the interdepartmental committee reports to it. That is likely to happen in the near future and we will all be able to act on the cabinet decision.

The member for Denison also mentioned a debate between himself and others and the parliamentary secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott), regarding a member of his staff who has apparently left and gone to join the staff of the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson). I am unable to answer his precise question off the top of my head as to the percentage of staff of ministers and parliamentary secretaries who are security checked through ASIO and through other means, but that information can be obtained.

As the member for Warringah said, the same processes that were in train under the previous government are still in place under this government. It is not all staff who have access to highly confidential or higher classified material, and I have no knowledge whatever about the individual status of that former member of the member for Warringah's staff.
Mr Deputy Speaker, I think I have dealt with all of the issues that have been raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —One issue that still needs clarification is the definition of Commonwealth offence. What happens in trials that involve Commonwealth offences and state offences, who is going to bear the brunt of that? You have a number of drug matters where the accused is charged with Commonwealth offences in relation to importation, and the accused could also be charged with state offences.

SPEECH.PARA: What happens in bankcard offences? If you are dealing with a Commonwealth bank, you have a mixture of Commonwealth and state offences. I am interested, and I am sure the parliament is interested at the moment, in what constitutes a Commonwealth offence and what will the Commonwealth fund? Are there areas of disagreement as to what does constitute a Commonwealth offence, or are the officials still deciding what the definition means?

The Attorney‐General has confirmed in his contribution today that the bean counters did get to this part of the budget. I think it is a false dividend. He talks about the efficiency dividend and the deficit and having to rein in the deficit, and at the same time he talks about a number of cases that will no longer be funded. That is going to produce false economies of scale because if an accused is not represented, will the judge discharge the accused because he or she cannot get a fair trial? If the judge does not discharge them, you will then have unrepresented accused and that will slow down the trial process. Trials that go for one week or less will go longer because the judge will be required to take more caution in terms of that trial.

I know this because I have had that experience. Jockey Smith was a classic when it came to representing himself. He could tie up the courts in New South Wales for six months at a time and then he would get legal aid on his appeal and get a fresh trial. That is what is going to happen.

When I was a public defender, when I was a legal aid solicitor, the efficiency dividend was applied overwhelmingly by having a legal representative in there who had, in effect, no incentive to prolong a matter. Cases were run efficiently. Accused were getting proper advice. Pleas of guilty were being conducted at an earlier stage. Sentence indications were given. It was churning over. These cuts are going to mean that people are not going to get legal advice. With no legal advice they are going to go into the courts and clog the system up. There will be pleas of not guilty when there should be pleas of guilty. This is going to have a multiplier effect.

That is why the judges are screaming blue murder. That is going to be the result. The bean counters are going to bring the system to a halt. There has been a clear message. Look at what the High Court has had to do. It has just had the efficiency dividend applied to it and it was left with two options: does it sit less often and not go around the countryside, or does it close to the public on weekends and public holidays? The High Court took the correct decision. That has meant that there is no access to that court on weekends and public holidays. The public cannot go through the court to familiarise themselves with the highest court in the land.

I think that the High Court was left with no option. The High Court should be quarantined from the efficiency dividend. Fancy placing the court in that position. You have the President of the Senate, Mrs Reid, attacking the court for that decision. They made the correct decision. To sit less often would have been the wrong decision. But that is something you can blame the bean counters for. Again, it sends the wrong message. There are some areas—and this is one of them—where they have got it drastically wrong, and time will show that.

BREAK.PARA: At the time when racism is being encouraged in this community, when there are more complaints of racial abuse and vilification coming at all levels in New South Wales and elsewhere, we go after HREOC. What kind of message does that send to the rednecks in the community? It says that government is responding to their low grade, prejudiced and ill‐informed concerns. You have the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) claiming credit for government policy. It sends the wrong message. HREOC was expanded, and specialised divisions are the way to go, in my opinion. We should be encouraging HREOC and Auditors‐General and a whole range of other independent watchdogs, not gutting them, which is what this budget has done. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to follow up on the points made by colleague, the member for Banks (Mr Melham) concerning the closure of the High Court on weekends and public holidays, and in particular the attack made on the administration of the High Court by my Canberra parliamentary colleague and President of the Senate, Senator Reid—uncharacteristically for her—a most unreasonable and unwarranted attack upon public servants doing a job for which the government had given them no choice.

—I regard Senator Reid as a good friend. We have worked together on many issues in Canberra over the years that we have both represented this area, particularly in the years when we both represented it in the Senate. SPEECH.PARA: In all that time she has had it pretty easy. It was easy for her to attack because if there were decisions she disagreed with, she was always in power so she could attack the government. If the first time they come it is not open, they can come back another time.

The Liberal government is essentially a Sydney government. It drives the people of Canberra quite mad when they see headlines saying, `Canberra decides . . . '. TALK.START.PARA: —Through North Shore eyes!
—Exactly. There are not too many of them out there in Blacktown being concerned about the policies—
—The Victorians wouldn't like that!

SPEECH.PARA: This closure is the first step down a road that denies Australians, wherever they live, access and the opportunity, equally, to see the best that Australia has to offer; and it is a decision that causes me great concern. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will approach the issue that was raised by the member for Banks (Mr Melham) from a slightly different perspective and take up the issue of cuts to the legal aid budget. It is plain that the budget savings that were proposed and put forward in the 1996‐97 federal budget will not be achieved. Whatever savings are ultimately achieved will be significantly less than were provided for in the budget, and so all the disruption and pain, all the destruction of national uniformity, and all the destruction of the work of the Legal Aid Board—which was established with a view to actually getting some coherence in the system—will be suffered for a return which will be nowhere near that which the Treasurer, Mr Costello, announced in relation to the budget.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate that some of these new arrangements are not yet in place and that some may never be put in place, because of the difficulties of negotiating them. But I would appreciate it if the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) could advise us of the difference between that which was set out as savings to be achieved in that budget and the ultimate reductions in Commonwealth expenditures that emerge, because the savings will be nowhere near those which were first projected. In other words, all this cost has been for very little gain to the budget, and certainly not the substantial gain to the budget that was projected. There will be a substantial shortfall.

I appreciate the Attorney‐General's undertaking to find and to tell us about the percentage of those in ministerial employment who have been subject to the scrutiny of the security services and the like. I would appreciate it, though, if he could give us some indication of whether that process has been attended to merely partially or comprehensively. It is a matter of grave concern if, after 18 months—notwithstanding that staff would have had to have been employed without the capacity of all of this to have been gone through beforehand—the scrutiny process is still substantially incomplete. Plainly, if that is so, we would wish to know why it is that that lack of responsibility—in terms of our perception of our vulnerability in these key areas—would be allowed to be sustained.

I appreciate the minister's willingness to provide some detailed advice relating to the cuts to the AFP. I wonder whether the minister could actually undertake to table or provide the menu as adjusted to take into account the ongoing funding reductions that that organisation is suffering. I do not accept that the only reductions have been those related to efficiency gains because, in fact, there have been associated detriments to the overall effectiveness of the AFP which I think go well beyond the normal burden that other organisations have had to suffer. I think there was an accelerated efficiency gain that was imposed.

I have two final points to make and, again, I appreciate the Attorney's comments in relation to the apparent inconsistency of the cabinet decision and the report in the Canberra Times, but I would appreciate the Attorney's assurance that he will fight to maintain merits review. It is not enough merely to observe that this inconsistency apparently has emerged within officials. Given that he has a cabinet decision which supports his position and, given that the Attorney does have a responsibility to ensure that fair processes are capable of being obtained by Australian citizens, whatever the arguments for or against better decisions, I would appreciate his undertaking that he will fight to maintain a fair system of administrative review with a merit system built in.

The final point I would make is in relation to a matter which overlaps with my immigration responsibilities. The Attorney would be aware of reports that a number of North Koreans, some of whom are alleged to have had significant criminal records of kidnapping, rape and other like offences, recently arrived in Australia on visitors visas. The Attorney may or may not be aware that I have publicly called for the minister for immigration to review those processes to advise us how this might have happened. I ask the Attorney: what steps, if any, are within his jurisdiction through the AFP to ensure that proper processes are in place so that people with serious criminal convictions do not get visitors visas to this country. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief in response. The member for Canberra (Mr McMullan) raised the question of the High Court closing at weekends, as did the member for Banks (Mr Melham). Both members will be aware that my department assisted the High Court in a review with a view to seeing what measures were open. A number of options were canvassed and two mentioned by the member for Banks were among them. Obviously it is better that the court close at weekends than the court cease to be an itinerant court.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the member for Canberra put it plainly when he spoke about tourism. The High Court budget is not a budget designed for tourist purposes. It is an advantage to the court that it is known to the community and it is seen to be accessible. It is open whenever the court is sitting—it is open on week days. Not every public institution that tourists would like to visit is open on weekends. If the Canberra Tourist Bureau would like to make a contribution to the High Court budget in order to assist, I am sure the High Court registrar would be pleased to receive the funding. I am told that it would, in fact, cost something like $8 per tourist to keep the High Court open on weekends, having regard to the number of people who visit.

The comments by the President of the Senate were obviously in defence of her constituency, as the member for Canberra's comments here today are in defence of his constituency, and I really make no further comment on them.

BREAK.PARA: The member for Denison (Mr Kerr) referred to a number of things. The cuts in legal aid will, in fact, achieve approximately what was set out in the forward estimates and I do not understand any suggestion to the contrary. The separate point which the member for Banks made, but I did not understand the member for Denison to be making in his comment, was that—
Mr Kerr interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We will have to wait until we have completed negotiations and revealed all the figures before you can conclude what has happened. There seems to be some misunderstanding on the part of commentators as to the nature of the arrangements that have been entered into, but it is not an appropriate time as yet to indicate what has been achieved. The point the member for Banks was making that, for example, an unrepresented litigant is going to impose additional costs on the budget, I think is at this point speculative. We need to monitor what is going to happen.

BREAK.PARA: Let me make the point that I intended to make earlier on. We have reached a point where the community has said, `This is the amount of money that is going to be available for legal aid.' If the courts have a different view as to what is required for legal aid, then the courts have two choices. One is that trials cannot go ahead and the other is that the courts can review and reform their processes. There is a lot that can be done. Legal aid has tended to be treated as a bottomless pit by some legal practitioners. Courts have not really had regard to the limited resources available to litigants, and the time has come when there should be a clear focus on that. I think the onus now, having regard to what has been achieved, is on the legal profession and on the courts.

TALK.START.PARA: —The definition of Commonwealth offence?

—The definition of Commonwealth offence has been under consideration and is effectively dealt with in guidelines that are being either put in place or negotiated, so that should not be an issue. I do not think the fact that there will be charges—as is already the case in some cases, both under state law and Commonwealth law—will be a problem, because it is a simple matter to have a pro rata charging of the legal aid funding to the state and to the separate Commonwealth sources. (Extension of time granted)

BREAK.PARA: The matter of the security check of ministerial and parliamentary secretary staff requires no further comment. The member for Denison is wrong in suggesting that the AFP has been subjected to additional cuts. It has had cuts in previous years. Some of those cuts were imposed by the previous government. They obviously have an impact, and they have a cumulative effect as well, but this year it is only an efficiency dividend.

On merits review, I am committed to merits review and I will obviously be participating in any review of the IDC report. The matter of the Korean immigrants is principally a matter for the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock). The AFP does provide advice to the department of that minister, as the member for Denison is aware, and will continue to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the AFP, the particular question was in relation to the menu of matters. The Attorney previously indicated there are obviously priority choices that must be made, depending on the level of funding of the organisation, and that that is part of the CLEB process. I would be grateful if an undertaking could be given in the public interest to provide both the previous menu and the current menu.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the member for Denison (Mr Kerr), I think I have said enough. Any further information can be provided in an appropriate way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the minister representing the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) in a position to provide the information which was sought in the Senate estimates committee about the difference between the coalition's pre‐election commitments to fund the Natural Heritage Trust, and the forward estimates of the previous government? The consequential questions that were asked related to the difference between the previous core funding for the environment, which was in place prior to the last election, and the reduced expenditure under the coalition as a result of the transfer of functions out of that core funding and other budget reductions. So the first question is: is the government yet in a position to identify what it says is the shortfall between previous core funding and current core funding?

SPEECH.PARA: The second issue I would appreciate the minister's advice on relates to the RFA process in our own state of Tasmania. As the minister may be aware, the RFA process in Tasmania is moving towards a conclusion, albeit it is unlikely to be concluded by the 30th of this month, as was anticipated at an earlier stage. One of the obvious issues which is causing concern to participants in that process is the question of the reservation of forest types on private land. By way of background, a simple summary, it is plain that the scoping agreement targets of reservations of 15 per cent of forest types that were in place pre‐1750 and the 60 per cent old growth and 90 per cent wilderness targets simply cannot be met in Tasmania, in any credible way, without massive destruction to the forest industry and without there being an associated preservation of some of those forest types on private land.

The difficulty emerges as to who is going to take funding responsibility and management responsibility for those reservations. At present, it is my understanding that the Tasmanian and Commonwealth governments are deadlocked on this issue. Why has the Commonwealth yet to ante‐up some serious proposal for it to take some responsibility to ensure the success of the RFA process? The Labor Party, in government, established the RFA process and wished that process to conclude to its successful end point. The current government asserted that it is committed to that. Yet the whole process could founder on the failure to provide a sufficient confidence in the system that necessary reservations on private land will be protected, not necessarily by acquisition, as some urge, but by at least some Commonwealth involvement in a management process and a commitment to necessary funding. This may need to be evolved should there become some issues of a compensation or the need to protect the forested areas from land clearances or from some other initiatives that might emerge down the track.

BREAK.PARA: Plainly, the state government has been placed in the budgetary position in which it has been placed by this Commonwealth government, with the massive reductions that have occurred—against a background which the minister would be aware of in our own state, where the state itself plainly does not have a financial capacity to meet those ongoing obligations yet the Commonwealth budget is moving into surplus. It is at least $187 million short of its pre‐election commitments on funding to the national trust to date and will not apparently ante‐up even a modest amount of money to secure confidence that forests on private lands can be built into an outcome in the RFA, which will enable us to have both an environmentally credible and an employment credible solution to that issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason that I want to make a contribution to the consideration in detail of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) for the Department of Environment, Sport and Territories is to restate my personal concern and very strong objection to the decision which the government made to premise any commitment to the improvement and maintenance of the Australian environment on whether or not it was able to sell one‐third of Telstra.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that that was one of the most indefensible abrogations of national responsibility which has ever been perpetrated by any national government in Australia. At the time of that debate, when that matter was being considered, I said that the government was, in effect, saying to the Australian people that—despite the fact that many of the great river systems of Australia are being serious degraded; despite the increasing salination of Australian rivers; despite the destruction of Australian forests, the degradation of the soils, the impoverishment of many of our coastal areas—if the Australian people and the Australian parliament were not prepared to allow it to sell one‐third of Telstra, then the Australian environment could go to hell.

That is what the government told us, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you know. That is what the government told the parliament, and that is what the government told the Australian people as well. If one‐third of Telstra were not to be sold, then the Australian environment—with all of that deterioration and degradation and the threat to Australia's future arising from that damage to the environment—could go to hell.

That was a deplorable decision. It was an abrogation of national responsibility in the extreme. It was one of the worst examples of a decision made by a national government that has ever been seen in Australia. I want to make this point as well: I have very serious reservations about the genuineness of the proposed Natural Heritage Fund. If one‐third of Telstra is sold and it realises what may be available from it—and that has been estimated at possibly $12 billion or $14 billion—then $1 billion of that will go into what has been referred to as the Natural Heritage Fund.

I am concerned about the genuineness of this government in the disbursement of those funds and the application of them to particular problems of the environment in Australia. I am concerned, because it simply repeats a practice which has become apparent in the operation of the government of Australia under the present coalition government. The other one is the Federation Fund. It is going to be interesting to see how those funds are applied, to which projects they go, and in whose electorates.

Another example is the reintroduction of a program called the roads of national importance. There is one road of national importance, Mr Deputy Speaker, for which you, in particular, have been persistent and courageous for years in pursuing work: the Pacific Highway. Money will be allocated to that, but I am concerned about where the rest of it will go. I believe very firmly and very genuinely that those funds will be used to pork‐barrel. There will not be a strict application of funds according to objective criteria and objective priorities.

We have thus got three examples. The Natural Heritage Fund has ostensibly been established to correct the degradation of the Australian environment. I will be watching to see what projects those funds are applied to. The Federation Fund will be another slush fund, another pork‐barrel fund. And the most recent one is the roads of national importance program. (Extension of time granted)

The particular project that I want to mention is the Natural Heritage Fund. As I said, I opposed the sale of Telstra and I opposed the funding of environmental programs and projects in that way. But since the decision has been made by the government—and presumably at some time in the future, then, the fund will be established—I want to put in a very strong bid for Lake Macquarie in New South Wales. Mr Deputy Speaker, it is not very far from you and I know that you are a frequent visitor to the beauties of that lake. It is the largest coastal saltwater lake in Australia. But, because of its location, because of the nature of the urban development that has taken place around it and because of the nature of the very high risk industries which have developed around Lake Macquarie—in particular, power generation and mineral concentration and processing—there has been some very serious degradation of Lake Macquarie.

Because those particular examples of degradation have taken place as a result of the national contribution which that region has made to the national economy and to the national welfare, I believe that a more than adequate case can be made out for restoration and remediation of the problems of Lake Macquarie being financed from national resources by the national government. I want to mark the spot as far as Lake Macquarie is concerned.

I have written to the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) asking that top priority be given to the needs of Lake Macquarie, in relation not just to some of the heavy metals that people have referred to recently as a particular problem but to the whole question of having an estuarine management plan developed. Very clear priorities can then be determined in relation to Lake Macquarie and appropriate funds can be provided to make sure that that magnificent lake system is returned to a pristine condition. It will be able to continue to make the very substantial contribution that it has made in the past to the future of Australia, not only in terms of urban development and industrial development but also because of the extremely important recreation and tourism role that it fulfils at the present time. It is one of the most magnificent saltwater lakes in the world and it must be preserved and restored.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a lot of environmental issues of concern in this great nation of ours today and if we had more time we could raise quite a few of them. The particular one I would like the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) or his representative in the chamber to be aware of is the proposal relating to the Fitzroy River, which is one of the great wild rivers remaining in Australia. The proposal is to dam the river and erect other irrigation infrastructure. I believe that that is something that he ought to consider. Certainly back in 1983 the Franklin Dam established the precedent and the right and responsibility of the Commonwealth to be involved in these issues.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the two or more dam projects that might be proposed on the Fitzroy River will almost certainly be located at Diamond Gorge, a remote and beautiful site north of Fitzroy Crossing. It is a haven for rare bird species, such as the gouldian finch, the purple‐crowned wren and also species such as the rock ringtail possum.

Tim Fisher—not the Deputy Prime Minister, but Tim Fisher of the Australian Conservation Foundation—has pointed out that a whole series of adverse environmental impacts would come from such a proposal, including significantly reduced wet season flows and much larger dry season flows, which would effectively reverse the natural flow patterns. In addition, the dams would create impassable barriers to fish, particularly migratory fish that have to move up and down stream to complete their live cycles, and the ecology of the river would be radically affected.

For these and many other reasons, I would urge the Commonwealth and the Minister for the Environment to be involved in this issue. The Fitzroy River is one of the last, long wild rivers remaining in Australia and, in my view, to dam it would be an environmental tragedy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer to the Department of the Communications and the Arts estimates that are also before us, with particular relevance to the arts matters. I will try, in terms of the agreement between the whips, to compress three or four issues into one and a half contributions because I know that we need to make sure the minister has some time to respond to a range of issues across a range of portfolios.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to first raise some issues concerning the film industry. Overall the film industry is in the position of the arts as a whole from this budget. They are expected to be thankful because the extent of the cuts this year is not as great as the extent of the cuts last year. The cuts are nevertheless substantial when looked at cumulatively. We have a small cut to the Australian Film Finance Corporation arising from the efficiency dividend. The efficiency dividend, however it is described, still comes from the program money available to the Film Finance Corporation this year. That was made clear in the Senate estimates.

We have on the face of it a $6.2 million cut to the Australian Film Commission, which is substantial, but underestimates the true position. The parliamentary library research indicates that in 1995‐96 the forward estimates were expected to increase to $50 million and yet we find the Film Commission budget at $29.7 million. On the face of it, there is a direct obvious cut on the budget papers, acknowledged by the government, of a cumulative $6.2 million to the Australian Film Commission. In fact, compared to the Labor government's planning, it is a much greater cut.

We have in addition the pressure on Film Australia, speculation about its privatisation and the uncertainty about what will happen there. In cumulative terms for this industry that means that we are cutting its research and development. That is essentially how the Film Commission is most simply described. It is more than that but is that. We are cutting its venture capital because that is essentially what the Film Commission and the Film Finance Corporation supply. Then this is compounded by the impact of cuts to the ABC.

The film and television industry is more than just an industry because it says a lot about us as a nation in its cultural role. In other circumstances, I would speak about that at length, but we have the agreement to be brief. I will not go into that. I will simply acknowledge that we must recognise it. It is a very important industry and it creates lot of jobs.

What I have been seeking, and what we did not seem to get out of the Senate estimates committee, is whether the government has made any assessment of the cumulative impact on production and employment in the film industry of the continuing cuts to the Film Finance Corporation, the Australian Film Commission and the ABC, let alone the prospective cuts to Film Australia. That is one matter on which I would like some response.

Secondly, I am concerned about the continuing speculation about the sale of Artbank. It might be fortuitous that it is under both the Communications and the Arts and Finance portfolios. We might be able to get some response on both accounts if the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Jull) is representing the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) here also.

Artbank has not for five years made any call on the budget and there is no prospect that it ever will. Yet by proposing to sell it there is a major threat to the income of emerging visual artists in Australia. There is a threat to the income of artists and private galleries where we have what I would have thought the conservatives would think is the ideal form of support for an industry, not grants but commercial purchases of the work of Australian artists against which a return is anticipated, that is being achieved.

What is the cultural or financial benefit that the government sees itself achieving by persisting with its attempts to sell Artbank? When it is going to stop the insecurity and the uncertainty that the continuing playing with this important enterprise is having in the visual arts in Australia and on that important organisation, Artbank? Those are the first two matters I wish to raise. (Extension of time granted)

The other two matters which I wish to raise, which I will try to do briefly, relate to the heading in the estimates concerning cultural development assistance and some matters to do with literature. In the cultural development assistance area, it is true that the cuts to the Australia Council and to cultural development assistance overall are not as great as last year. On the face of it they seem small, but when we start looking at them we find more emerges.

I would like to get some clarification about the details of the $1.5 million cut in cultural development assistance to fund the ongoing activities of the Visions of Australia program. I was the minister who initiated the Visions of Australia program. I welcome the fact that the government has made a continuing commitment to it, even if only till 1998‐99. I would rather it had been more substantial through the forward estimates period, but even that is welcome. But to do so, it is not extra money for the arts. The arts area is being called upon to fund this by other cuts, and nobody yet knows where that cut is going to fall.

We also have the problem that, following last year's two per cent across-the-board cuts to all the great Australian arts institutions funded through the major organisations fund of the Australia Council, we see the evidence this year that virtually all of those agencies are suffering great stress because of the difficult economic times, which is putting pressure on sponsorships and ticket sales. There is nothing in this budget to assist those organisations and nothing to compensate for the two per cent cut last year. We still find the funding for the Australia Council at less than the 1995‐96 funding. What does the government have in mind to assist Australian arts in general and, in particular, my current concern, which is the major national organisations and the major organisations fund?

The other hidden cut in the budget is to the National Film and Sound Archive. I welcome the commitment to build the new building for the National Film and Sound Archive. It was a scandalous decision last year to cancel the commitment of the previous budget to build a new building. I welcome the fact that there is now some funding through the Department of Finance to meet part of the cost of a new building. But when we look, what we find is that at least half the cost of that building is going to have to be met by cuts in the other ongoing activities of the National Film and Sound Archive and the Department of Communications and the Arts. That has not been made public, but it is clear, on the face of it, and what we want to know is: what are the implications of those cuts for the other programs of the National Film and Sound Archive and for the arts in general?

I have not got time to talk about the public lending rights; I have discussed that before. I think this government has led a most mean spirited attack upon arts in Australia, but I will discuss that on another occasion.

I want to ask one question about libraries. The government went to the election with a commitment of $11.4 million for what has now become known as the on-line public access initiative, merely to match a budgeted commitment of the previous government. But it obviously was not a core promise because what you have provided was $2 million, not $11.4 million. That was in the last budget.

I understand, and I would like the minister to confirm, that applications were received for $25 million of funding under that program. Last week a distribution of the $2 million was announced. There is nothing further in this budget. What prospect is there of your $11.4 million promise ever being met?.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Sport, Territories and Local Government; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALKER.NAME: Mr WARWICK SMITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker and members for your contributions. Given the limitation of time, I will try to do justice to those matters, and what matters I cannot deal with I will undertake to get some answers on for honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Denison (Mr Kerr) raised several matters. The first one was with regard to overall funding for the environment and whether core funding, the promise that had previously been made, had indeed been met. We undertook, prior to the last election, that we would spend an additional $1.15 billion over the five years, on top of the previous government's forward estimates. That is an average of about $230 million each year. In 1995‐96, the previous government spent $212 million on environmental programs, and your forward estimates for 1997‐98 were $171 million on environmental programs.

In 1997‐98, we will spend $255 million, an increase of $84 million, a 50 per cent increase. Your forward estimates for next year, that is 1998‐99, were to be $147 million. So we will spend in 1998‐99, $267 million on environment programs, an increase of $120 million. That is an 80 per cent increase. And this is despite the environment program having to find savings announced in last year's budget of $34 million to help repair, of course, the deficit that we inherited.

In other words, the environment programs—when you look closely at the figures against what we said we would do, and against your own forward estimates which were part of what our undertaking was—are contrary to what you have said and contrary to what I read recently in The Age by Kenneth Davidson, and in yesterday's Bulletin. I think that they are the basic figures that one should start with and then, in addition, of course, there is the Natural Heritage Trust.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you assert core funding is?

—I do not think that is appropriate. The point that we made was that we would undertake to spend in addition and above to meet the $1.15 billion target ahead of your forward estimates. And they are the figures. I understand that they have been put down in the estimates, as well, by Senator Hill.
—But you are not answering the question.
—That is the information that Senator Hill has put down—
—I am sure it is, but it does not answer the question.

—I believe that it does answer the question. The other issue that was brought up by the member for Denison concerned the RFA process. It related to the question of private land and how that would be treated in the process of the negotiations. The negotiations, I can report to the Chamber, are at a penultimate stage. We may meet the 30 June date—one is still hopeful. Negotiations and discussions are continuing with all the relevant parties.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of the preservation and reservation of the private land to which you refer, is an issue that is actively being considered by the states and the Commonwealth, as you would appreciate. The point that was made by the member for Denison was that are there are ways in which acquisition, or a management process, or funding, or compensation, or other such initiatives might emerge to give effect to the desire to reserve significant species within private forestry to meet the overall criteria of the CAR reserve system under the Janis criteria. I accept the point that is being made by the member for Denison. These are very difficult issues but we, like any sensible people within the broader parliament, would want to get an RFA that is successful, to give some sustainability and certainty in the forest industries.

How that might be funded, if indeed funding is required, is a matter that is actively being considered by my colleague Senator Hill and by me when I assume the position, as I did last week, of Acting Minister for the Environment, and I am sure, if that occasion arises again, that I will give it very active consideration. (Extension of time granted) The point about mining issues—because they were involved in the RFA process—involves my colleague, Senator Parer. The member for Charlton (Mr Brown) basically made three points. The fact, of course, is that the parliament has approved the sale of Telstra and therefore given effect to the government's policy. So I acknowledge your right to make the points that you have but, of course, the parliament has chosen to go in a different direction from that of your own views.

Concerning your question about the NHT, the genuineness of the fund, we believe that the process of assessment of projects involves states, local government and independence of the technical assessment panels. I am sure that they, for example, would be looking closely at the applications for Lake Macquarie funding. We are very cognisant of the need to have a fund of that size vested with genuineness and integrity and we have tried to put in place processes that will deliver those particular outcomes.

The first project of the Federation Fund was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) as being the National Museum here in Canberra. We are developing criteria about the assessment but, broadly, they will be major items such as a national museum that will be looked at in conjunction with the states around the nation. That too will be a transparent process.

Roads of national importance—the other point you made—do not really fall into either of the portfolios that I am involved in. From your remarks, and as a former minister for roads, I think you appreciate the need for such a program. That is a matter for my colleague Minister Sharp. I think there has broadly been a very warm welcome of that proposal by local government, and indeed federal members and states, as being a necessary matter to pursue. I take notice of the points made by the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson). It was not part of the budget process, but I am sure that comments that he has made will be passed to Senator Hill.

The member for Canberra (Mr McMullan) raised a range of issues, all of which I do not think I am going to be able to do justice to at the moment, partly because I do not have all the information. Some of it may have been dealt with in estimates, but I will undertake to find out the points that you have referred to.

Broadly speaking, you asked the fundamental core question of whether or not there has been any assessment of the cumulative impact of the changes that have arisen in the budget with regard to the film industry. The information that I have, provided by Senator Alston, does not answer that question specifically, but it does point out that the funding for the Film Finance Corporation was maintained. There was a reduction of $5 million in the television production fund to which you referred, but there are continuing access arrangements for the tax deductibility for films, which I think you acknowledged, if I recall your remarks.

Concerning your point about the R&D being reduced, in a sense that is still available through the tax deductibility provisions. The TPF fund still continues, but it has been reduced. That, of course, is to meet broader budget objectives so it may not be quite as detrimental as you point out.

On the issue of Artbank and the continuing uncertainty, the government is still considering that matter and the points that you made are, of course, noted. I make the point that I know there is no diminution of the personal commitment from the minister responsible in this area, Senator Alston. I am sure that he will be making decisions that will give effect to recognising the qualities in Artbank. Whether it should be operated by government or by some other private arrangement is the issue that government will have to decide upon. They will obviously be considering that matter in some detail and will make a decision in due course.

Concerning the cultural development assistance and the $1.5 million cuts to the Visions of Australia program, which you yourself commenced, it has been indicated that that will be continuing and you have welcomed that. We certainly welcome that. Concerning maintenance of the funds for the Australia Council, those funds are actually maintained at the same level as in the previous budget, as I understand it. That is important.

On the issue of the library, I simply do not have any information about that, and I do not have any knowledge on that matter but, as I understand it, funds have been applied. Your point was whether or not the amount that is applied is equal to the amount that was anticipated to be applied—some $25 million versus the $11 million. I would assume that what is taking place here is funding over a period of time. There is a commitment to library matters.
That is the sum total of the comments that were made. If I have missed any matter, if members want further information, please let me know and I will undertake to provide it.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Electoral Commission: Production of Street Lists

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Australian Electoral Commission charge federal Members of Parliament to produce a street list for their electoral divisions; if so, will he consider providing those lists to Members as part of the resources available in the discharge of their duties.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Members of Parliament have no entitlement, under the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, to the free supply of street list information.

The AEC currently maintains a printed list of streets for individual federal Divisions. Requests for street lists from Members of Parliament will be met on a cost-recovery basis, and only if resources are available. However, as this product was developed for AEC internal use, it may contain street information in a format that is not suitable for use by Members.

While the AEC does not have the resources to undertake computer programming to meet requests for the supply of street information in non-standard formats, the ongoing review of AEC requirements may lead to the development of a more suitable product which could then be made available to Members of Parliament.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 14 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the Minister's answer to part (1) (c) of question No. 1476 (Hansard , 14 May 1997, page 3591), concerning the level of airborne asbestos fibres in Wittenoom and Telstra's decision to no longer install or maintain services in that area, how low does the level have to be before Telstra is not concerned.
(2) Will Telstra disclose the levels of airborne asbestos at (a) Tom Price, (b) Paraburdoo and (c) Newman, including levels after blasts.

(3) Is the Minister able to say whether Austel (a) does not consider two pay phones to be a substitute for the discontinued service and (b) believes that Telstra has an obligation to maintain existing services.
(4) Are persons in remote areas entitled to have their services maintained.
(5) Further to the Minister's answer to part (4) of question No. 1476, is the Minister able to say whether Mr Blount pays tax in Australia on his salary.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Sport, Territories and Local Government; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Telstra has advised that it is concerned to abide by recommendations made by a competent authority, in this case the Western Australian Government, which has posted Wittenoom as an area sufficiently contaminated with asbestos fibres as to be dangerous to a person's health. Telstra is concerned that the health of its employees is not put at risk by requiring them to enter the Wittenoom township to perform work associated with installing and maintaining telecommunications services.

(2) Telstra is not in the business of measuring asbestos contamination levels itself but does respond to the monitoring of such contamination by relevant Federal and State bodies. As far as Telstra is aware, no agency has raised the issues of extensive, residual asbestos contamination in Tom Price, Paraburdoo and Newman.

(3) I am advised that service to Wittenoom has not been discontinued. Telstra has entered into an interim agreement with the residents of Wittenoom to maintain the existing service, so long as it can be maintained, or until permanent service arrangements (as described below) can be implemented. The agreement calls for Wittenoom customers to hire a contractor to assist in the maintenance of the service. Telstra has agreed to reimburse the residents of Wittenoom for all reasonable costs associated with such maintenance and to train the contractor.

Telstra and Wittenoom residents have reached an agreement in principle regarding permanent telephone service to the town. A new network boundary will be established outside the asbestos contaminated area. The residents of Wittenoom will be responsible for terminating the town's telecommunications distribution facilities at the new network boundary. Telstra will be responsible for providing network access at that point.

Under the proposed arrangements, Wittenoom residents will hire a contractor to extend distribution facilities to the boundary and maintain the services within the asbestos contaminated area. Telstra will reimburse the Wittenoom residents for all reasonable costs incurred in the maintenance of the service, including labour, training, equipment and materials.

In Telstra's view, these arrangements will allow the residents of Wittenoom to fully enjoy the advantages of a modern telecommunications network, while offering appropriate protection to Telstra's employees.

(4) Telstra's Universal Service Obligation is to ensure that standard telephone services, payphones and prescribed carriage services are reasonably accessible to all people in Australia on an equitable basis, wherever they reside or carry on business, including remote areas.

(5) No—As indicated in response to Question No. 1476, it is inappropriate to provide details about an individual's taxation affairs which remain a matter between the taxpayer and the Australian Taxation Office. This approach is consistent with the requirements of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 which includes specific secrecy provisions to protect the confidentiality of taxpayer information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 27 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Is Shepherds Hill Cottage in Newcastle protected by a covenant prohibiting the use of the cottage for other than historical or recreational purposes; if so, will the Commonwealth invoke its authority under the covenant to restrain development of the site which is in conflict with the objectives of the covenant.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Shepherds Hill Cottage is protected by a covenant. Clause 2 of the covenant states `The Transferee shall not use or permit to be used the land and any improvements thereon for any purposes other than as a historical and recreational site provided however that the cottage on the said land (being the cottage known as `No 45 The Terrace, Shepherd's Hill'), may be occupied as a home for an artist-in-residence or for any similar purposes not inconsistent with the said historical character.'

If any proposed use of the cottage contravenes clause 2 of the covenant the Commonwealth would be entitled to obtain an injunction from the Supreme Court of New South Wales restraining the State of New South Wales from so using the cottage. Should a use which contravenes the covenant be approved by the State of New South Wales, the Commonwealth would consider invoking its authority under the covenant.
